comment: So, if quantum computers can drain bank accounts and manipulate stock markets, what makes us think their impact on Bitcoin will be contained to "only" 25% of coins? We should be looking at this as a systemic risk, not just a crypto-specific one.

children: So, if quantum computers can drain bank accounts and manipulate stock markets, what makes us think their impact on Bitcoin will be contained to "only" 25% of coins? We should be looking at this as a systemic risk, not just a crypto-specific one.

, Research indicates that only about 25% of Bitcoin (about 4M BTC) is vulnerable to quantum computing attacks because this portion is stored in specific address types where the public key is exposed. These include Pay to Public Key (p2pk) addresses, mainly from early Bitcoin usage, and reused Pay to Public Key Hash (p2pkh) addresses, where the public key becomes visible after the first transaction. A quantum computer could potentially use advanced algorithms to derive the private key from these public keys, allowing attackers to steal funds.
The majority of Bitcoin, stored in unused p2pkh addresses, is not currently at risk because their public keys are not publicly known. However, there is some uncertainty about whether all Bitcoin could become vulnerable during transactions, depending on future quantum computing advancements and mitigation strategies.
And yes, I agree, quantum computing is a systemic risk that can potentially affect the entire online world, that's exactly what I outlined in this article.
